newsitem.title: UK: UK's Internet Bookshop in virtual share offering.
newsitem.headline: UK's Internet Bookshop in virtual share offering.

text.p: The Internet Bookshop, a book retailer, said on Thursday it had became the first company in Europe to offer its shares to the British public across the Internet.

But due to security in the fledgling world of business across the Internet, those hoping to subscribe will have to download a form, fill it in by hand, attach a cheque, and mail it, not e-mail it, by old-fashioned post or "snail-mail" as web fans call it.

The share offering is being used as a showcase for Microsoft Corp Internet technology, according to Microsoft Europe's marketing manager Andrew King. "The Internet Bookshop is a great example of a company that built their business on Microsoft's Internet platform," he said.
The Internet Bookshop is the world's second largest distributor of books across the Internet after Amazon in the United States, with over 850,000 titles available.
But while the firm's list of titles includes every book published in the UK, business and academic publications account for around 70 percent of the company's trade.
Under the offering private investors will each be able to apply to purchase up to 9,500 Internet Bookshop shares at one pound ($1.61) each out of a total of 250,000 set aside for the general public.
And for those purchasing 500 or more, the company is offering a 10 percent discount on any of its books, according to Darryl Mattocks, founder and managing director of The Internet Bookshop.

Listed on Microsoft UK's home-page and on the world-wide web at www.bookshop.co.uk, the Internet Bookshop is selling a total of one million shares which will trade on OFEX, a private stock exchange listing small UK companies and operated by brokerage JP Jenkins.
Mattocks said 750,000 of the shares had been placed with a number of institutional investors in the UK and abroad.
"This is the first time in Europe that shares will be offered across the Internet with the consent of all regulatory bodies," Mattocks said.
Previously an IT consultant, Mattocks set up the Internet Bookshop in 1993, but when it came on-line in June 1994 business was initially very slow.
"We didn't sell a single book for the first two months," Mattock said. But the tide seems to have turned, and January produced the company's best ever sales.
The firm sold 7,492 books during the period, producing sales of 120,000 pounds.
"We are looking for turnover to increase at least four-fold during 1997," Mattocks said. Turnover during 1996 totalled 568,162 pounds on sales of 19,000 books.
Proceeds of the share offering will help reduce the company's 200,000 pounds debts and will fund the 100,000 sterling flotation, leaving the firm with a balance of 700,000 sterling, Mattocks said.
